author: By Iris Zaki, Tamir Elterman and Jonah M. Kessel
title: ‘I Don’t Have That Empathy. It’s Not in Me Anymore.’ What Israeli Survivors Believe Now.
description: Survivors of the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks grapple with what can be recovered and what is lost forever.
content: After Hamas attacked their country this month, many Israelis fled to hotels, where they sought some version of safety. There, they’ve been processing their trauma as they move from that harrowing morning into a new world. In the Opinion video above, filmed in the days after the attack, survivors reflect on what they lost, whom they blame and what’s next — for them and for Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Lauren Jackson
title: Gaza’s Vital Tunnels
description: Hamas needs its maze of tunnels to fight. But more than two million people live above the underground network, a layer of human life between military targets and Israeli missiles.
content: There is a transportation network below Gaza, one that Israel is trying to destroy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Prabal Gurung and Jessel Taank Kick Off New York’s Diwali Season
description: Business and entertainment leaders of South Asian descent celebrated the holiday at the Pierre on Saturday night.
content: The Pierre hotel on the Upper East Side sparkled on Saturday night as a group of business and entertainment leaders of South Asian descent, joined by friends, kicked off the Diwali season in New York in feathered lehengas, bedazzled saris and gold-stitched sherwanis at the All That Glitters Diwali Ball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant and David McCabe
title: Google C.E.O. Says Tech Giant Has Improved the Web for All Consumers
description: Sundar Pichai, the chief executive of Google, appeared in court to defend his company against a landmark federal antitrust case.
content: As Google’s chief executive, Sundar Pichai, tells it, his company has always been on the side of consumers. It has paid billions to other industry giants, like Apple and Samsung, he said, to make sure Google’s internet search engine worked as well as it should on those companies’ devices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Nicole Tung
title: Both Sides Pay a Bloody Price for Coveted Ukrainian City
description: The fight for the battered city of Avdiivka has emerged this fall as the fiercest battle of the war. Waves of Russian assaults have not broken through so far.
content: The tall chimneys of the Avdiivka Coke Plant stand out against the skyline. Beside it a sprawling slag heap juts into the sky, offering a high point overlooking the city of Avdiivka and surrounding villages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Cecilia Kang
title: Biden to Issue First Regulations on Artificial Intelligence Systems
description: In an order to be issued on Monday, the White House will outline requirements that the most advanced A.I. products be tested to assure they cannot be used to produce weapons, among other regulations.
content: President Biden will issue an executive order on Monday outlining the federal government’s first regulations on artificial intelligence systems. They include requirements that the most advanced A.I. products be tested to assure that they cannot be used to produce biological or nuclear weapons, with the findings from those tests reported to the federal government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag
title: Cornell Jewish Center Under Guard After Online Threats to Jewish Students
description: “We will not tolerate antisemitism at Cornell,” the university president said after threats were made against the Center for Jewish Living.
content: Follow live updates on the Israel-Hamas war and Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Desperately Seeking Da Silvano
description: For decades, Silvano Marchetto’s Greenwich Village trattoria was a celebrity haven, serving Brad Pitt, Beyoncé and Jay-Z. Then he vanished. What happened?
content: One recent morning, in the bustle of Florence’s ancient central market, Silvano Marchetto, a stout 76-year-old man with a mane of white hair, sat nursing a Negroni as he considered what he wanted to cook for dinner. The butchers and fishmongers who walked by threw respectful nods his way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric A. Taub
title: Southern California Beyond the Freeway
description: There’s history around every curve on the back roads between Los Angeles and Los Olivos, a 100-mile route that meanders through mountains, canyons and star-studded enclaves.
content: Perhaps nothing defines Los Angeles like the freeways: ribbons of asphalt and steel (and traffic jams) tying coast, valley and mountains together in a multilane, limited-access web. These highways were considered so essential that planners nearly jammed one right through the center of swanky Beverly Hills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac
title: X Says It Is Worth $19 Billion, Down From $44 Billion Last Year
description: The social media company’s valuation was disclosed in the paperwork for stock grants that it handed to employees on Monday.
content: X, the company formerly known as Twitter, handed out stock grants to employees on Monday that showed it was worth about $19 billion, down about 55 percent from the $44 billion that Elon Musk paid to buy the firm a year ago, according to internal documents seen by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.J. Goldmann
title: Review: ‘Chicago,’ With Nary a Finger Snap
description: Barrie Kosky’s Berlin production of the 1975 musical adds a touch of burlesque and a dash of Bertolt Brecht.
content: The seedy, culturally vibrant and rapidly modernizing Berlin of the 1920s was nicknamed “Chicago on the Spree.” That moniker sprang to mind recently during the premiere of a masterful and muscular new production of “Chicago,” directed by Barrie Kosky at the Komische Oper Berlin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: Doctors Wrestle With A.I. in Patient Care, Citing Lax Oversight
description: The F.D.A. has approved many new programs that use artificial intelligence, but doctors are skeptical that the tools really improve care or are backed by solid research.
content: In medicine, the cautionary tales about the unintended effects of artificial intelligence are already legendary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Run-Up' Team
title: The Run-Up Returns, Every Week Through Election Day
description: It could be 2020 all over again. That’s what makes 2024 so different.
content: We’re just about a year away from Election Day 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Books Staff
title: 16 New Books Coming in November
description: Barbra Streisand’s mammoth biography, Stephanie Land’s follow-up to “Maid,” Sigrid Nunez’s new novel and more.
content: In Auster’s new novel, an aging philosophy professor struggles to move on after the accidental death of his wife nearly a decade earlier. The book shuttles between present and past, between a solitary life of writing and a passionate, decades-long relationship that continues to haunt him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: At Ballet Theater, a Thrilling Puck and a Moment to Take Stock
description: Jake Roxander’s soaring Puck in “The Dream” was the highlight of American Ballet Theater’s final two programs this fall, the first season programmed by Susan Jaffe.
content: Mendelssohn’s music for “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” is full of sweet thunder and other wonderful noises. A cartoon sound effect for jumping isn’t among them. Yet when American Ballet Theater performed Frederick Ashton’s ballet “The Dream” last Saturday, every time Jake Roxander’s Puck took to the air, I could swear I heard one: “boing!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In the Early Days of Lockdown, a Writer Considers a Perplexing Age
description: Set during the pandemic, Sigrid Nunez’s new novel, “The Vulnerables,” is a story of unlikely companionship and personal reflection.
content: Animals and uncomfortable topics: Count on these in a Sigrid Nunez novel. Her slim, discursive, minor yet charming new one, “The Vulnerables,” is no exception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wyatt Mason
title: Sigrid Nunez’s Art of Noticing
description: The National Book Award winner smuggles profound reflections on pain and loss into novels of deceptive lightness.
content: We began outside on Adirondack chairs still heavy with dew, the 72-year-old American novelist Sigrid Nunez preferring the shade. It was a cloudless morning in mid-August in Middlebury, Vt., and I had gone to meet Nunez, a petite woman of almost suspicious good cheer, to talk about her half-century-long writing career. She had come up from her home in New York City to give a reading — from her new, ninth novel, “The Vulnerables,” which appears this week — at the Bread Loaf Writers’ Conference. Through time, Robert Frost, Toni Morrison and George R.R. Martin have all read at Bread Loaf. Nunez was joining those names, an unlikely advent. She didn’t publish a novel until she was in her 40s and wasn’t able to live on her writing until — 47 years after she began — she won the National Book Award, at 67, for “The Friend.” That novel became an international best seller, translated into more than 30 languages. I wondered how Nunez had managed such persistence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leily Nikounazar
title: Famed Iranian Rights Lawyer Reportedly Jailed and Beaten
description: Nasrin Sotoudeh was one of several activists arrested at the funeral of Armita Geravand, a 16-year-old girl who died after not wearing a head covering in public, in a case that drew parallels to that of Mahsa Amini.
content: A prominent Iranian human rights lawyer, Nasrin Sotoudeh, was arrested and severely beaten, her husband said on Monday — one of several activists taken into custody at the funeral in Tehran of a girl who was fatally injured after a reported confrontation with the enforcers of Iran’s strict dress code for women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: War Closes In on Gaza City
description: The latest from the Israel-Hamas war. Weekday afternoons with Lulu Garcia-Navarro and Times journalists on the ground.
content: After a weekend of debilitating airstrikes and a communications blackout, the Israeli military moved deeper into Gaza, and appeared to be approaching Gaza City from at least three sides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: The Latest Target for California Conservatives? Local School Boards
description: Several California school districts have required parental notification when students seek to change their gender identity. Opponents say the policies have needlessly divided communities.
content: Bill Essayli had no chance of getting one of his first bills through the California State Assembly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: Matthew Perry Was One of TV’s Best Sparring Partners
description: Perry will always be remembered as Chandler on “Friends,” but his performances in shows like “The West Wing” and “The Good Fight” revealed his subtle gifts as an actor.
content: TV flags are flying at half-staff today, with the news that Matthew Perry died on Saturday. The influence and persistence of “Friends” is hard to overstate, and Perry’s nimble, endearing performance as Chandler Bing is tattooed on the hearts and brains of anyone who watched TV in the 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano and Christine Hauser
title: In Europe, Meta Offers Ad-Free Versions of Facebook and Instagram for First Time
description: Starting in November, subscriptions will cost between 9.99 euros and 12.99 euros per month, the company said.
content: Meta said on Monday that it will introduce an advertisement-free subscription option for Facebook and Instagram for the first time beginning next month for users in Europe, a sign of how government pressure is leading large tech companies to change their core products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Colorado Trial Considers Whether the 14th Amendment Disqualifies Trump
description: Some constitutional experts argue that a clause in the amendment should bar Donald J. Trump from becoming president again, but that view is far from universal among legal scholars.
content: Something the nation has never seen before began playing out in a Denver courtroom Monday morning: a trial to determine whether a major party’s likely presidential nominee is eligible to be president at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Is the Pantyhose-as-Pants Look a Real Thing?
description: A reader who sees pants-less celebrities on runways and on social media wonders if the rest of us are actually expected to follow suit.
content: It’s true: Pantyhose (one of the most unappealing names for a garment ever invented) have been on the rise for a few seasons now, after disappearing almost entirely from many wardrobes as women not in the British royal family were freed from some of the more egregious dress code strictures of the past century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: ‘You Won’t Find a Richer, Crispier, Creamier, Cheesier Mac and Cheese Recipe’
description: Millie Peartree’s Southern macaroni and cheese recipe is a snap to make and gets rave reviews.
content: With Halloween jumping out at us tomorrow, and Thanksgiving waiting around the corner, the season is sporting its brightest colors. The trees are rubicund with turning leaves; the farmers’ market ruddy with apples and pumpkins; the impulse rack in the supermarket checkout line ablaze with beckoning bags of candy corn. What better match for this resplendent palette than the melty orange Cheddar bubbling on top of reader favorite Southern macaroni and cheese?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Israel’s Emergency Medical Service to Receive $88 Million in Gift Led by Michael Bloomberg
description: The former New York City mayor and billionaire philanthropist said he would match $44 million in donations from nearly 34,000 people.
content: Michael Bloomberg said on Monday that he would donate nearly $44 million to Magen David Adom, Israel’s nonprofit emergency medical service, after the Hamas attacks on civilians and soldiers on Oct. 7.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Tuesday Briefing: Israeli Forces Advance on Gaza City
description: Plus we remember Matthew Perry.
content: The Israeli military advanced deeper into the Gaza Strip yesterday, approaching Gaza City, the enclave’s largest city, from three directions as it battered the territory with airstrikes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Middle East War Could Cause Oil Price Shock, World Bank Warns
description: A new report outlined how a major escalation of the conflict between Israel and Hamas could fuel a new bout of inflation.
content: A major escalation of the war between Israel and Hamas — one that spilled over into a broader Middle East conflict — could send oil prices surging as much as 75 percent, the World Bank warned on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: A Vibrant Center in Oakland Has Nurtured Disabled Artists for Nearly 50 Years
description: Artists from Creative Growth who are developmentally disabled have shown their works at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, the Pompidou Center in Paris and beyond.
content: It’s Monday. A vibrant center in Oakland has nurtured disabled artists for nearly 50 years. Plus, how California became America’s contemporary music capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘Stereophonic,’ the Rock Revolution Will Be Recorded
description: David Adjmi’s riveting new play, with songs by Will Butler, is about a ’70s band that nearly destroys itself making an epochal album.
content: It’s an imperfect rule of thumb that musicals lift up and dramas drill down. So what do you call David Adjmi’s “Stereophonic,” which does both?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: London City Ballet Is Revived, Nearly 30 Years After It Shut Down
description: The company folded in the 1990s with mounting debts. Can a rebooted troupe thrive at a time when similar British organizations are scaling back?
content: London City Ballet, a company that dissolved almost 30 years ago, is set for a reboot, just as other British performing arts groups are cutting costs and reining in their ambitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Federal Judge Reinstates Gag Order on Trump in Election Case
description: Judge Tanya Chutkan ruled that her order should stay in effect while the former president’s lawyers pursue an appeal.
content: A federal judge reinstated a gag order on former President Donald J. Trump on Sunday that had been temporarily placed on hold nine days earlier, reimposing restrictions on what Mr. Trump can say about witnesses and prosecutors in the case in which he stands accused of seeking to overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: Near an Acapulco Beach: Food, Water and Prayer After Hurricane Otis
description: Dozens of displaced locals gathered in a converted shelter, waiting for resources to be delivered to their ravaged city.
content: In a large church displaying a big blue cross near the Acapulco beachfront, dozens of people dozed in sleeping bags along the pews, prayed in silence or anxiously discussed their next move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Rami Nazzal
title: Settler Violence Against Palestinians in the West Bank Is Rising
description: More than 100 Palestinians have been killed, more than 2,000 injured and nearly 1,000 forcibly displaced by Israeli settlers since Hamas’s Oct. 7 attacks on Israel, the United Nations said.
content: Attacks on Palestinians in the occupied West Bank are surging, with at least 115 killed, more than 2,000 injured and nearly 1,000 others forcibly displaced from their homes because of violence and intimidation by Israeli forces and settlers since Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7, according the United Nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Fauzia
title: Dust Might Have Snuffed Out the Dinosaurs
description: A simulation suggests that fine particles played a stronger role in cooling the planet and stalling photosynthesis after an asteroid impacted the Earth.
content: On a spring day over 66 million years ago, an asteroid slammed into the sea just off the coast of modern-day Mexico. Known as the Chicxulub impact, it set off a global shock wave, earthquakes and megatsunamis that exterminated the nonavian dinosaurs and plunged Earth into a long and dark winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Louis Oliver Gropp Dies at 88; Led Shelter Magazines Through Turmoil
description: He turned House & Garden into an upscale chronicle of the good life in the 1980s, and broadened the focus of House Beautiful in the 1990s.
content: Louis Oliver Gropp, a steady shepherd of shelter magazines through decades of turmoil as editor in chief of House & Garden, Elle Décor and House Beautiful, died on Oct. 17 at his home in Greenport, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Jessica Cheung, Sydney Harper, Rachelle Bonja, Rikki Novetsky, Patricia Willens, Lisa Chow, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Israel’s Invasion Begins
description: The ground operation, which began on Friday, remains shrouded in secrecy.
content: Over the weekend, the Israeli military appears to have begun an invasion of the Gaza Strip, with tanks rolling into the enclave and Israeli soldiers fighting Hamas inside. But the operation remains shrouded in secrecy, and Israel is revealing little about its actions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Will France’s Strict Cheesemaking Rules Bend for Climate Change?
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 30, 2023.
content: “The history of French cheese is a love story between men, animals and the earth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley and Tom Mashberg
title: Tracing Treasures of Ancient Rome to a Village That Looted Its Own Heritage
description: Investigators say they have figured out how bronze statues from a shrine built 2,000 years ago in Asia Minor to venerate the emperors of Rome ended up in museums around the world.
content: One towering ancient bronze was found last year in the Sutton Place apartment of a notable New York philanthropist. Another this year in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. A third bronze, the head of a young Roman boy, was seized from Fordham University in March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: What 2023 Work of Art or Culture Would You Warn Others to Avoid?
description: What movie, book, video game, album, show, restaurant or other work or experience disappointed you this year? Why?
content: Is there something you have read, watched, listened to, eaten, visited, played or otherwise experienced this year that you think is so bad that you want to discourage others from experiencing it? If so, what and why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender and Michael Gold
title: How Trump’s Verbal Slips Could Weaken His Attacks on Biden’s Age
description: Donald Trump, 77, has relentlessly attacked President Biden, 80, as too old for office. But the former president himself has had a series of gaffes that go beyond his usual freewheeling style.
content: One of Donald J. Trump’s new comedic bits at his rallies features him impersonating the current commander in chief with an over-the-top caricature mocking President Biden’s age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Reaction to Matthew Perry’s Death Shows Enduring Popularity of ‘Friends’
description: The sitcom’s final season was nearly two decades ago. But it remains popular on traditional TV and on streaming.
content: “Friends” concluded its 10-season run nearly two decades ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Union Victories May Lift Biden, as U.A.W. Targets Tesla and Others
description: President Biden’s support for autoworkers helped them make big wage gains, and labor organizers are looking to bring about similar gains elsewhere as carmakers transition to electric vehicles.
content: The United Automobile Workers’ big wins with Detroit’s Big Three automakers could also prove to be a significant political victory for President Biden, who openly sided with striking workers to pressure the companies, General Motors, Ford and Stellantis, to produce generous concessions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Speaker Mike Johnson and the Role of Religion in Politics
description: Readers discuss how his evangelical Christianity will influence his new role. Also: Jewish anguish; Penn donors; shoplifting; college athletes.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Judge Orders Border Agents to Stop Cutting Texas’ Barbed Wire Fence
description: The wrangling over concertina wire along the Rio Grande is the latest legal battle between Texas and the Biden administration over border security.
content: In the latest chapter in an expanding legal struggle over border security, a federal judge in Texas ordered federal Border Patrol agents on Monday to stop cutting concertina wire that had been placed by the state along the Rio Grande to deter migrants from crossing from Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner, Lauren Leatherby, Vivian Yee and Aaron Boxerman
title: Israelis Advance on Gaza City, as Netanyahu Rules Out Cease-Fire
description: Israel’s leaders vowed to destroy Hamas, which controls the Gaza Strip, after the deadly Oct. 7 attack, and Israeli ground forces are closing in on the city from three directions.
content: Israeli forces on Monday advanced from three directions toward the battered and densely populated Hamas stronghold of Gaza City, slowly pushing deeper into the Gaza Strip while battering the territory with airstrikes and renewing evacuation warnings to people and hospitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: The Star of Half Baked Harvest Inspires Loyalty — and Controversy
description: From her hilltop compound, Tieghan Gerard has built a recipe empire and a nearly impenetrable bubble.
content: Tieghan Gerard was busy lighting pumpkin spice-scented candles when I arrived at her sunlit studio last month. After more than a year of negotiations with the representatives who guard her schedule and her image, she’d agreed to cook two recipes I’d chosen from the thousands on her immensely popular recipe site, Half Baked Harvest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Window for Meeting Key Climate Goal Is Even Narrower Than Thought
description: Limiting warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius would be harder than ever, new calculations show, but less ambitious targets are still in reach.
content: Five years and change. That’s how long humans can keep pumping carbon into the atmosphere at our current rate before we’re likely to push global warming past the most ambitious limit set by the Paris Agreement, according to new estimates released Monday by a team of climate scientists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Hearing Aids Are More Affordable, and Perhaps More Needed, Than Ever
description: Over-the-counter devices have been available for a year now. New research suggests they may have unexpected benefits.
content: A year ago, the Food and Drug Administration announced new regulations allowing the sale of over-the-counter hearing aids and setting standards for their safety and effectiveness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay and Eric Schmitt
title: Top Marine General Hospitalized After Apparently Having Heart Attack
description: The episode happened as the service’s No. 2 position has been left unfilled because of a senator’s blockade on promotions of senior military officers.
content: Gen. Eric M. Smith, the Marine Corps’s commandant and top officer, was hospitalized on Sunday evening after an unspecified medical emergency, the service said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Teenagers as Critics: A Step-by-Step Guide for Writing a Review
description: We’ll walk you through the process with advice from New York Times critics and student writers.
content: So you want to write a review. Whether you are planning on entering our Student Review Contest, writing an assignment for class, or submitting a piece to a school, local or online publication, this guide can help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang and David E. Sanger
title: Biden Issues Executive Order to Create A.I. Safeguards
description: The sweeping order is a first step as the Biden administration seeks to put guardrails on a global technology that offers great promise but also carries significant dangers.
content: President Biden signed a far-reaching executive order on artificial intelligence on Monday, requiring that companies report to the federal government about the risks that their systems could aid countries or terrorists to make weapons of mass destruction. The order also seeks to lessen the dangers of “deep fakes” that could swing elections or swindle consumers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: When George Santos Called and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
description: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: $23,500 in Coins to Pay a Settlement? Judge Says Keep the Change and Try Again.
description: A Colorado judge ordered a welding company to use a check or other conventional method to pay a settlement after it tried to deliver 6,500 pounds in coins.
content: Pennies, nickels, dimes and quarters might be legal tender but more than 6,500 pounds of loose change is not a proper form of payment, a Colorado judge ruled last week after a defendant attempted to deliver $23,500 in coins to settle a legal dispute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Tale of Two Recoveries
description: The city has regained its lost private-sector jobs, but the new jobs don’t pay as well as the old ones, and middle-income New Yorkers are struggling.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at a major milestone in the city’s recovery from the pandemic — and why there’s more to the city’s economic outlook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Your Connections Questions, Answered
description: Wyna Liu, Connections editor, answered reader questions about the game.
content: Our newest game, Connections, is the perfect mix of challenging and fun. During an hourlong Q. and A. in our comments section, Wyna Liu, the editor who creates the game boards, answered your burning questions about the puzzle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3.5 Million Homes in California
description: A midcentury-modern home in Los Angeles, a 175-acre ranch with two houses in Healdsburg and a Spanish-style retreat in Palm Springs.
content: This house is in the Doñas, an area in the Studio City neighborhood populated with midcentury homes. It is close to Laurel Canyon, less than five minutes from Laurel Canyon Dog Park and about 10 minutes from Hollywood. The Fryman Canyon trailhead, popular with hikers and dog walkers because of its views of the Hollywood Hills, is also nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: At New York’s ‘Friends’ Museum, Mourning Matthew Perry
description: The day after the actor’s death, fans paid tribute at a storefront re-creation of the sitcom’s famous sets.
content: Every night, Marnie Stein, an elementary school principal from Montreal, falls asleep to the lullaby of “Friends” streaming on her TV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Wanda Poltawska, 101, Who Forged a Friendship With a Future Pope, Dies
description: She survived gruesome medical experimentation at the Ravensbrück concentration camp to become a psychiatrist — counseled by the priest who would become John Paul II.
content: Wanda Poltawska, a Polish psychiatrist and author who after World War II sought spiritual help to cope with the horrors she had experienced in a Nazi concentration camp and became a lifelong friend of her counselor, a priest who would one day be Pope John Paul II, died on Oct. 24 at her home in Krakow. She was 101.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Safiullah Padshah and Elise Blanchard
title: ‘I’m Starting Again From Zero’: Afghans Pour Out of a Hostile Pakistan
description: More than 70,000 undocumented Afghans have returned home in recent weeks to meet a Wednesday deadline ordered by the Pakistani government.
content: The grandfather always feared this day would come.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Oct. 30, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 30, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Autoworkers Strike a Blow for Equality
description: Is this a turning point for unions — and shared prosperity?
content: It’s not officially over yet, but the United Auto Workers appear to have won a significant victory. The union, which began rolling strikes on Sept. 15, now has tentative agreements with Ford, Stellantis (which I still think of as Chrysler) and, finally, General Motors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany, Matthew Goldstein and J. Edward Moreno
title: Prosecutors Turn Sam Bankman-Fried’s Own Words Against Him
description: Asked during his cross-examination about his public statements and how he ran his crypto empire, the FTX founder repeatedly said he couldn’t remember.
content: When the cryptocurrency exchange FTX was riding high, Sam Bankman-Fried, the company founder, communicated with the public in a relentless torrent of tweets, TV interviews and pronouncements in front of Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Vineyard
title: Could Matthew Perry’s Chandler-Speak Be Any More Memorable?
description: In “Friends,” Perry lobbed his character’s distinctive linguistic style deep into the national consciousness.
content: Matthew Perry, the actor who died on Saturday at 54, had a distinctive linguistic style that he lobbed deep into the national consciousness. His Chandler Bing on “Friends” was too clever and cool for traditional TV catchphrases: Try to imagine him saying “Bazinga!” or even his roommate Joey’s “How you doin’.” Instead it was how Perry spoke, with an infectious inflection, that pushed his musical Chandler-speak into the American vernacular.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Should School Be a Place to Celebrate Halloween?
description: Some districts have banned costumes and parties in an effort to be inclusive of people who don’t participate in the holiday. Do you think this is a good solution?
content: Halloween is almost here. Will Oct. 31 be a regular day at your school or are there plans for celebrations? Will students and teachers dress up in costume? Will any of your classes have Halloween-themed lesson plans or “Monster Mash” playing while you work? What about the cafeteria menu — will there be items like spooky spaghetti or black and orange cookies?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Leah Remini Lists Her Los Angeles Home a Third Time
description: Ms. Remini, the actress now known as an outspoken critic against the Church of Scientology, is asking for $12.5 million for the six-bedroom house she bought 20 years ago.
content: The actress Leah Remini has listed her home in the  picturesque Studio City neighborhood of Los Angeles — and is doing so at a price cut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberto Patiño
title: I’ve Seen It: Maduro Could Lose Venezuela’s Presidential Election
description: Venezuela will hold its presidential election in 2024 — one that Maduro can lose, as long as the opposition stays united.
content: Nicolás Maduro has been in power for 10 years in Venezuela. In that decade, he has overseen a period of economic collapse, corruption, a sharp increase in poverty, environmental devastation and state repression of dissidents and the press. This has led to an exodus of more than seven million Venezuelans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola, Gabby Sobelman and Aaron Boxerman
title: Shani Louk, Believed Kidnapped, Was Likely Dead When She Was Taken by Hamas, Family Says
description: Shortly after the Oct. 7 attacks, Hamas released a video showing a woman lying face down and mostly naked in the back of a pickup truck. Ms. Louk’s mother said the woman was likely her daughter.
content: Shani Louk, a 23-year-old German-Israeli citizen believed to have been abducted by Hamas militants while attending a music festival on Oct. 7, was most likely killed before she was taken into Gaza, her family said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Blink-182 and the Rolling Stones Bring Rock Back to the Top 10
description: The pop-punk heroes’ latest LP debuts at No. 1, and the Stones’ first collection of original songs in 18 years opens at No. 3.
content: New releases by Blink-182 and the Rolling Stones score high on the Billboard album chart this week, while the music industry waits to see just how gigantic Taylor Swift’s latest rerecording will turn out to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter
title: KKR Closes Deal to Buy Simon & Schuster
description: The process of selling Simon & Schuster has been long and tumultuous, and was waylaid by an earlier antitrust suit.
content: The private equity firm KKR completed its acquisition of Simon & Schuster, one of the biggest and most prestigious publishing houses in the United States, on Monday, marking a major shift in the publishing industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: ‘You Can’t Hide It’: Georgette Heyer and the Perils of Posthumous Revision
description: A new edition of the best selling romance writer’s 1950 novel removes blatant Jewish stereotypes, stirring debate about whether to tinker with older works.
content: Georgette Heyer, one of the most popular and influential romance authors of all time, was not a romantic when it came to her work. “I ought to be shot for writing such nonsense,” she once declared in a letter to her publisher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan K. Stack
title: I’ve Been Under Bombardment. There Must Be a Cease-Fire in Gaza.
description: What outcome does Israel’s strategy avert that would be worse than the outcome it has already created?
content: Getting bombed from the sky is a particular horror: The sense that death hangs quite literally over your head, invisible until it’s too late, and maybe it will hit you. Maybe this moment. Or this. Or this. Every heartbeat hammering through your skull.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnatan Reiss and Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel announces the first rescue of a soldier abducted on Oct. 7, a 19-year-old woman.
description: She was abducted after Hamas gunmen overran and briefly captured a military base in Nahal Oz, just east of the northern Gaza Strip.
content: The Israeli military said on Monday that it had rescued an Israeli soldier who was abducted from an Israeli army base on Oct. 7 and taken to Gaza during the Hamas-led terrorist attacks in Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: How Music Can Be Mental Health Care
description: In music therapy, clients play and listen to music as treatment for stress, depression and anxiety. Here’s how it works.
content: The therapy session begins when Isobell, 17, picks up a guitar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Patent Fight That Could Take Apple Watches Off the Market
description: A federal trade agency ruled that some Apple devices infringe on patents held by other companies.
content: Apple Inc. sells a lot of smart watches during the holidays, but this year its sales of most Apple Watch models may well drop 100 percent — to literally zero — the day after Christmas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Govan
title: Robert Irwin Helped Us See the Light
description: Being with Irwin as he watched and questioned everything around him, I learned that a work of art succeeds when it challenges our perceptions.
content: Robert Irwin, who died last week in San Diego, at 95, had one of the most restless, inquiring minds of any artist I have ever known. As the story goes, in 1966 he stepped back from one of his very ethereal, so-called abstract “dot paintings” — composed of small dots of near-complementary colors — and realized that the visceral, rather than optical phenomenon created by the painting was not the painting itself but rather the real and beautiful shadow cast by the canvas against the wall. He never made another painting. From that point forward he wanted to make works of art without frames, without limits, which he did, continually questioning the very nature of art in almost every visionary work he made.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Netanyahu Rejects Calls for a Cease-fire — and for His Resignation.
description: Israel’s prime minister adopted a defiant tone in a rare news briefing, saying that the country would not agree to a halt in attacks because, he argued, doing so would strengthen Hamas.
content: Striking a defiant tone at a rare news briefing on Monday evening, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel ruled out a cease-fire in Gaza, dismissed calls for his resignation and rejected criticism of Israel’s strikes on civilian homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag
title: Hochul Visits Cornell to Reassure Jewish Students Rattled by Online Threats
description: “I want them to know they are not alone,” New York’s governor said of the students, after posts on a student forum called for violence against Jews.
content: In the wake of online posts threatening violence against Jewish students and institutions at Cornell University, Gov. Kathy Hochul on Monday visited the campus in Ithaca, N.Y., to condemn the posts as hate speech and lay out the steps her administration is taking to help keep students safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Riot Over Plane From Israel Alarms Jews and Draws Condemnation
description: A mob in the Russian republic of Dagestan stormed runways looking for a flight carrying Jewish passengers. The episode highlighted the threat of ethnic strife in Russia.
content: An uprising in southern Russia, where rioters stormed an airport tarmac apparently searching for Jewish passengers on a flight from Israel, has shocked Jews in Russia and beyond, drawn condemnation from the Israeli government and prompted the Kremlin to call an unscheduled meeting to address the clashes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Israeli forces move deeper into Gaza
description: Also, G.M. strikes a tentative deal with autoworkers
content: The Israeli military advanced on Gaza City from at least three sides today as it battered the enclave with airstrikes. The deepest reach, about three miles, paralleled the Mediterranean coast toward the Shati refugee camp on the northern flank of the city. Here’s a map showing locations of Israeli troops in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Police Were Told Maine Gunman Had Threatened to Carry Out Shooting Spree
description: The Army Reserve and a Maine sheriff’s department knew of a reservist’s deteriorating mental health five months before he carried out America’s deadliest mass shooting this year.
content: The Army Reserve and a Maine sheriff’s department were aware of a reservist’s deteriorating mental health more than five months before he killed 18 people in Lewiston, Maine, according to records released on Monday. Just six weeks ago, the records show, he had grown increasingly paranoid, punched a friend and said he was going to carry out a shooting spree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
title: Under Shroud of Secrecy, Israel Invasion of Gaza Has Begun
description: After an air campaign that killed thousands of Palestinians, Israel has begun a ground assault, but it took hours for outside observers to understand what was happening. The ambiguity was intentional.
content: When Israeli ground forces advanced en masse into the Gaza Strip on Friday evening, just after the Jewish Sabbath began, they did it so secretly that it was hours before the outside world understood what had happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: Why Oslo Still Has Relevance
description: The hopes briefly raised by a handshake 30 years ago can be more than a sad footnote to history.
content: A few days after Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin was assassinated on Nov. 4, 1995, I remember an Israeli acquaintance telling me that however terrible the circumstances of his death, it had established Mr. Rabin as a martyr for peace. As a result, the Oslo peace process he had begun, named after the city where it was secretly hatched, had become irreversible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: ‘A Very Slow Game:’ Why the Pace of Israel’s Ground Operation Counts
description: Israel’s invasion of Gaza is proceeding more slowly than expected. That may suit the needs of its allies — and its adversaries, analysts say.
content: In the 23 harrowing days since Hamas attacked Israeli civilians and soldiers, Israel’s Western allies have had to perform a delicate balancing act: expressing steadfast support for the country during its darkest hours, while navigating the growing public anger on their streets over the intensifying bombardment of Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: F.D.A. Experts Will Vote on Safety of a Cure for Sickle Cell Disease
description: The treatment from the company Vertex would be the first medicine to use the gene editing tool CRISPR.
content: On Tuesday, Oct. 31, an advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration will consider a gene editing treatment for sickle cell disease, a potentially deadly, excruciatingly painful, lifelong condition in which blood cells are deformed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Abu Bakr Bashir and Iyad Abuheweila
title: ‘One Would Rather Die With His Family’: Some See No Point in Fleeing Gaza.
description: As bombs fell in the background, Palestinians in the Hamas-ruled territory recounted a struggle to survive.
content: As the Israeli tanks started rolling near Gaza City on Monday, the whispers began to spread — terrifying in their specificity, terrifying in their vagueness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Lempicka,’ New Musical About Art Deco Artist, to Open on Broadway
description: Rachel Chavkin of “Hadestown” will direct the show, which had developmental productions in Massachusetts and California.
content: “Lempicka,” a new musical about the painter Tamara de Lempicka, will open on Broadway next spring after a decade in development.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, David E. Sanger and Edward Wong
title: Biden’s Support for Israel Now Comes With Words of Caution
description: The administration has become more critical of Israel’s response to the Hamas attacks, a shift that U.S. officials attribute to the humanitarian crisis in Gaza.
content: Three days after Hamas terrorists slaughtered more than 1,400 people, President Biden offered Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu support in the wake of the vow by Israel’s leader to “avenge this black day” and to turn Hamas hide-outs “into a ruin” from the air and on the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed and Francesca Jones
title: Plans to Slash Emissions at Britain’s Largest Steel Plant Cause Unease
description: Tata Steel wants to close polluting blast furnaces in Port Talbot, Wales, but employees worry that their jobs will go, too.
content: Two hulking towers nearly 300 feet high rise from the steel-making complex that dominates the shoreline of the faded industrial city of Port Talbot in Wales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: ‘Utterly Devastated’: ‘Friends’ Cast Reacts to Matthew Perry’s Death
description: Perry, who portrayed Chandler Bing, died on Saturday. He was 54.
content: Matthew Perry’s fellow “Friends” cast members expressed their grief and sadness about his death in a joint statement to People magazine on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: A Leaning Tower in Italy (Not Pisa) Becomes a Worry
description: City officials in Bologna have closed a city-center square as they study what to do about the Garisenda Tower. A solution could take years.
content: The Garisenda Tower in Bologna is not as famous as the Tower of Pisa, but it leans a little more. Lately, though, the dynamic of its movement has become worrisome, and city officials decided recently that the central square where it stands a few meters apart from the much taller Asinelli Tower will be closed off, most likely for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Shipping Contributes Heavily to Climate Change. Are Green Ships the Solution?
description: The container shipping lines that carry the bulk of global trade are betting on greener technologies, but there are still reasons those wagers could fail.
content: On a bright September day on the harbor in Copenhagen, several hundred people gathered to welcome the official arrival of Laura Maersk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amaney Jamal and Keren Yarhi-Milo
title: The Discourse Is Toxic. Universities Can Help.
description: Campuses must protect free speech but equally advocate mutually respectful dialogue.
content: The conflict in Israel and Palestine has thrown American campuses and society into turmoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Fly By Jing’s New Chile Crisp Captures the Flavors of Chengdu
description: Brooklyn Kura expands its Industry City space, Jacques Pépin releases a new cookbook and more food news.
content: Chile crisp or crunch has become as ubiquitous in the kitchen as peanuts on a bar. Depending on whose jar you’re opening, there are slight variations. A new one that’s densely packed with soybeans, fava beans, yellow split peas and pumpkin seeds doubles down on the crunch factor. The fire component is moderate. It’s from Fly By Jing, a source for Sichuan-style condiments made in China and sold online and in stores. Jing Gao, the entrepreneur in charge, said she was inspired by her hometown, Chengdu, for this one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Seeking the ‘Right’ Customers, an Insurer Is Accused of Discrimination
description: Erie Insurance defends its practice of telling agents to use subjective factors when judging a potential customer. Maryland regulators say the company sought to exclude Black and Hispanic people.
content: When regulators in Maryland said this spring that the small company Erie Insurance had illegally avoided selling policies to people in mostly Black neighborhoods, Erie had a ready answer: It said it was being singled out for simply doing business as usual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Why Less Engaged Voters Are Biden’s Biggest Problem
description: His weakness is concentrated among those who stayed home in the midterms but who may show up in 2024.
content: If you’re looking to reconcile the surprisingly strong Democratic showing in the midterm elections with President Biden’s weakness in the polls today, consider the political attitudes of two groups of respondents from New York Times/Siena College polls over the last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Trump’s Children Are Set to Take the Stand at His Fraud Trial This Week
description: The former president himself is scheduled to testify in the civil case on Nov. 6 as the trial enters its second month.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump will testify early next month in a trial that threatens the business empire that is the foundation of his public persona and informed his run for the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Neal E. Boudette
title: Autoworkers Score Big Wins in New Contracts With Carmakers
description: Tentative accords at Ford Motor, General Motors and Stellantis are the most generous in decades, raising costs as the industry shifts to electric vehicles.
content: A six-week wave of strikes that hobbled the three largest U.S. automakers has resulted in tentative contract agreements that would give workers their biggest pay raises in decades while avoiding a protracted work stoppage that could have damaged the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Stream These 10 Movies Before They Leave Netflix in November
description: We rounded up the best titles leaving the streaming service for U.S. subscribers next month. That includes Oscar winners, family favorites and bawdy comedies.
content: Family favorites, Oscar-winning (and nominated) acting, bawdy comedies and insightful documentaries are among the highlights of the titles leaving Netflix in the United States in November. (Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Michael Levenson
title: Matthew Perry’s Cause of Death Remains Under Investigation
description: Perry was found unresponsive in a hot tub at his house in Los Angeles on Saturday, the police said. It could be weeks or even months before the cause of his death is established, experts said.
content: As the authorities continued to investigate the death of the “Friends” actor Matthew Perry, experts cautioned Monday that it could take weeks or months for the cause to be determined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff and Katie Thomas
title: How a Lucrative Surgery Took Off Online and Disfigured Patients
description: More surgeons are opting for a complicated hernia repair that they learned from videos on social media showing shoddy techniques.
content: The bulge on the side of Peggy Hudson’s belly was the size of a cantaloupe. And it was growing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump Is Still Far Ahead in Iowa Poll, With Haley Matching DeSantis for 2nd
description: Former President Donald J. Trump leads his closest competitors by 27 percentage points in a new Des Moines Register poll, but Nikki Haley has surged to tie Ron DeSantis.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump still has a huge lead in Iowa, according to a poll released Monday, but Nikki Haley has surged to tie Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida for a distant second place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Democratic Rifts Over Israel Burst to the Forefront in Congress
description: The divisions are erupting as the House weighs a G.O.P. bid to censure the only Palestinian-American member of Congress for criticizing Israel and votes on a large aid bill to back Israel in the war in Gaza.
content: Israel’s war against Hamas is exposing deep divisions among Democrats in Congress, as the most outspoken supporters of the Jewish state and vocal pro-Palestinian members on the left trade accusations of bigotry and feud over what role the United States should play in the hostilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniela J. Lamas
title: A Brutal Disease May Soon Be Transformed
description: A new treatment for sickle cell disease will change lives — but how many?
content: The sickle cell crises were always different. Sometimes Lynndrick Holmes would wake up with a searing pain in his legs, as though there were knives growing out of his bones. Sometimes it was in his arms, like needles digging into his nerves. Other times it was in his chest. The air felt heavy and every breath burned as though there were a barbed wire cage around his lungs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Most Hyped, Most Anticipated, Most Gossiped-About Collection Is Finally Here
description: Phoebe Philo returns with her own line on her own terms: No shows. No advertising. Just very good stuff.
content: Almost six years after leaving Celine, the brand she transformed into one of the most influential fashion lines in the world, and a little more than two years after revealing that, wait — she was actually coming back, and under her own name, Phoebe Philo the messiah (sorry, designer) has finally returned to fashion with Phoebe Philo the brand. Can you hear the hosannas? Her first namesake collection is possibly the most hyped, most anticipated, most gossiped-about new line from a formerly beloved name … well, ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: What to Know About the Automakers’ Deals With the U.A.W.
description: With tentative agreements in place, a six-week strike against Ford, General Motors and Stellantis could soon come to an end. But the union’s rank-and-file members still need to approve the deals.
content: The United Automobile Workers union reached a tentative agreement with General Motors on Monday, following similar deals in recent days with Ford Motor and Stellantis, the parent company of Ram, Chrysler and Jeep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: scattershot
description: This word has appeared in 46 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word scattershot has appeared in 46 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 2 in “‘The Bear’ and a Chaotic Vision of Work” by Melissa Kirsch:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: Watching Britney Spears, as a Girl and a Woman
description: For 25 years, American culture has used her body to determine a woman’s worth. In “The Woman in Me,” she asks us to take a second look.
content: There is a moment in Britney Spears’s new memoir when she is summoned to an MTV studio and made to review footage of strangers complaining that she was “too sexy.” Spears, then 18, had just performed at the 2000 Video Music Awards, where she had torn off a sparkly black tuxedo to reveal spangled nude pants and a spangled nude bra, and various pedestrians roving Times Square had decided that she had crossed a line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Keith Giffen, Comic Book Maverick for DC and Marvel, Dies at 70
description: A celebrated illustrator and writer, he brought sardonic wit to franchises like Justice League and to offbeat creations like Rocket Raccoon and Ambush Bug.
content: Keith Giffen, a celebrated comic book artist and writer who began his career when comics were still on the fringes of popular culture, in the 1970s, but who rode the superhero wave toward the mainstream with DC Comics’ Justice League and Marvel’s Guardians of the Galaxy, popular franchises that became Hollywood films, died on Oct. 9 in Tampa, Fla. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Frank Howard, Towering Slugger Whose Homers Were, Too, Dies at 87
description: At 6-foot-7 and 250-plus pounds, he was known for his tape-measure blasts for the Dodgers and the Senators — not to mention all those strikeouts.
content: Frank Howard, the Bunyanesque slugger who struck some of baseball’s more awesome home runs for the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Washington Senators while rolling up a prodigious strikeout total as well, unable to conquer his penchant for chasing bad balls, died on Monday in Aldie, Va. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Global Race to Regulate Artificial Intelligence Is Heating Up
description: President Biden is set to issue new rules on the technology, days ahead of an international summit on A.I. safety.
content: President Biden is set to issue an executive order on artificial intelligence on Monday, in his first effort to regulate how U.S. companies develop it and how regulators oversee the technology. The order will create standards for American companies and public agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Tariq Panja
title: FIFA Bars Former Spanish Soccer Chief for 3 Years
description: Luis Rubiales, who led the country’s soccer federation, departed in disgrace after he forcibly kissed a player after the Women’s World Cup final.
content: Soccer’s global governing body on Monday barred Luis Rubiales, the former president of Spain’s soccer federation, from the sport for three years over his forcible kiss of a player after the Women’s World Cup final in August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Dickey
title: The Hidden Ghosts of America’s Slave Past
description: Ghost tours offer a kind of history that might not be found in a museum; they can also tell you how a city sees itself.
content: I had come to Charleston, S.C., in search of ghosts. So I signed up for one of the many “haunted Charleston” nighttime walking tours of the “Holy City.” A few hours later, I wandered through the historic French Quarter, flanked by other tourists searching for a thrill. Gas lights flickered over decaying structures, cobblestone alleys, and houses that were at least a century old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Buffy Sainte-Marie’s Indigenous Parentage Is Questioned
description: An investigation by the CBC disputed a key part of Sainte-Marie’s story, saying that a birth certificate shows she was born to a white family in Massachusetts.
content: The parentage of Buffy Sainte-Marie, a folk singer known for her activism on behalf of Indigenous people, was questioned after CBC News reported that it had found a birth certificate indicating that she was born to white parents in Massachusetts, and not on a Piapot Cree reservation in Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: U.A.W. Says It Aims to Organize Nonunion Auto Plants
description: After outlining gains for Ford workers in a live-streamed speech, Shawn Fain, the union president, said he was setting his sights on other automakers.
content: After winning major gains in wages and benefits from two of the three Detroit automakers, the United Automobile Workers union is looking beyond the Motor City to car companies operating nonunion factories across the South.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser, Nicholas Fandos and Tracey Tully
title: How Menendez Tried and Failed to Place an Ally in a Key Federal Post
description: An old friend of Senator Robert Menendez was in legal trouble. The government says the senator went to great lengths to try to install a friendly prosecutor.
content: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey had a problem — and, prosecutors say, an opportunity. An old friend and political patron was facing federal prosecution. And as New Jersey’s senior senator, Mr. Menendez was in a position to help, by recommending the next leader of the office overseeing the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: What 2023 Work of Art or Culture Would You Recommend to Anyone?
description: What movie, book, video game, album, show or other work from this year has exceeded your expectations? Why?
content: Taylor Swift, Beyoncé, Barbenheimer. This has been a blockbuster year for art and culture. Have you been impressed by what has come out so far?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Monday Briefing
description: Israel is ‘expanding’ ground operations in Gaza.
content: The Israeli military yesterday signaled a heavier assault on Gaza and warned with increasing “urgency” that Palestinian civilians should move to the southern part of the Gaza Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Lionel Messi Wins Eighth Ballon D’Or as Soccer’s Best Player
description: Messi is the first M.L.S. player to win the award. Aitana Bonmatí of Spain won the women’s prize.
content: The Ballon d’Or, the most prestigious individual soccer award of the year, rewards the best player over a 12-month period. But Lionel Messi essentially won it in just about a month late last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Cars Seized by Police Get Supreme Court Scrutiny in Civil Forfeiture Case
description: Several justices seemed wary of allowing law enforcement officials to take vehicles used to commit crimes when their owners were not at fault.
content: The Supreme Court seemed torn at an oral argument on Monday about whether to make it easier for people whose cars or other property were seized by the police to argue for their prompt return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Adler-Bell
title: Do Any of These Never Trumpers Have the Power to Persuade?
description: Three new books from different corners of conservative America talk about the ways Donald Trump disfigured the country and wrecked their public lives.
content: Miles Taylor, a former Department of Homeland Security official in the Trump administration and the author of the new book BLOWBACK: A Warning to Save Democracy From the Next Trump (Atria, 335 pp., $30), made his dramatic entrance in 2018 with an anonymous essay for The New York Times entitled “I Am Part of the Resistance Inside the Trump Administration.” In it, he heralded the “unsung heroes” who were “working diligently from within” to impede Trump’s “worst inclinations.” The following year, having resigned from the D.H.S., Taylor published “A Warning,” also under the moniker “Anonymous.” Finally, in 2020, Taylor criticized Trump under his own name, endorsed Joe Biden and identified himself as “Anonymous.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: Energy Dept. Pours Billions Into Power Grids but Warns It’s Not Enough
description: America’s electric grids may need to expand by two-thirds by 2035 to handle future growth in clean energy, the agency said. The nation isn’t on track.
content: The Energy Department on Monday announced $1.3 billion to help build three large power lines across six states, part of a new gusher of money from Washington to upgrade America’s electric grids so they can handle more wind and solar power and better tolerate extreme weather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Larry Buchanan, Josh Katz, Eve Washington and Rumsey Taylor
title: An Extremely Detailed Map of New York City Neighborhoods
description: More than 37,000 New Yorkers told us where their neighborhoods start and end. We mapped them all.
content: More than 37,000 New Yorkers told us where their neighborhoods start and end. We mapped them all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: A Little Momentum for Marijuana
description: Earlier this month, three cousins finally opened ConBud, one of New York’s first licensed marijuana dispensaries.

author: By Iris Zaki, Tamir Elterman and Jonah M. Kessel
title: ‘I Don’t Have That Empathy. It’s Not in Me Anymore.’ What Israeli Survivors Believe Now.
description: Survivors of the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks grapple with what can be recovered and what is lost forever.

author: By Mona El-Naggar, Neil Collier, Danielle Miller and Mark Boyer
title: War Through the Eyes of Gaza’s Children
description: At a U.N. camp in southern Gaza, children have been forced to flee their homes and live in squalid conditions while trying to make sense of a war with no end in sight.
content: At a U.N. camp in southern Gaza, children have been forced to flee their homes and live in squalid conditions while trying to make sense of a war with no end in sight.
